Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Causal Representations in Children's Transitive Sentences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement grant will support the work of doctoral student Melissa Kline under the direction of Dr. Edward Gibson.

The structures of sentences contain clues to their meanings. A nonsense sentence like "The dax gorped the blicket to the voom" allows for some initial guesses: 'gorping' probably means something about sending or transferring. The research carried out in this project will address the issue of how children learn the rules that match sentence meanings with sentence form. An important test for this question is a basic sentence type, the transitive sentence (e.g. "Jane broke the lamp.") Across languages, transitive sentences are reliably used to describe causal events, but some languages like English also allow for other kinds of meanings (e.g. "Jane liked the lamp.") Even so, adult speakers tend to expect new transitive verbs to refer to causal events. Do children use a similar strategy to help them learn new verbs? Depending on the learning biases children use and the input they hear from their parents, children might make very different guesses than adults about new verb meanings.

To test these questions we will examine the guesses that toddlers make about the meaning of a novel word like 'daxing.' Co-PI Kline will also use conversation transcripts to compare these guesses to the transitive sentences that parents actually say to their children. Currently, we know that children have a broad preference for certain scenes to match with transitive sentences: a girl pushing a boy in a wheelbarrow is a better guess for "The girl daxed the boy" than a girl and a boy waving their arms separately. In this research Ms. Kline will use what is known about causal perception to create closely matched scene contrasts to discover the specific cues and features that children associate with transitive verbs.

This project will contribute to our understanding of how children learn verbs and sentence structures and of how conceptual representations are related to language. Funding this project also contributes to the training of a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How children learn to use language to express structured relationships - even simple ones like "I broke the lamp" - is a difficult challenge, one that is critical to understanding what it is that children are accomplishing as they learn their first language. As they do this, children learn that this general form (I X'd the Y) often (though not always) describes a cause-and-effect relationship.  But what do we mean by a cause-and-effect relationship? It turns out that developmental cognitive scientists have developed some theories of what young children know about causal relationships (for instance, to make and object change, you usually have to touch it.) But since the language input is messy and there are many other differences in the verbs that fit into this construction, it is not clear if or whether children should hone in on this specific aspect of meaning, as opposed to something else like "an event that has two participants (Me and the Y)"  We tested whether preschoolers make this specific prediction by showing them scenes that were identical except for this causal relationship: so one puppet might touch a toy to make it turn on, while another would aproach the toy but not touch it, and then the toy would turn on apparently spontaneously.  Even though both events contained the same characters/objects and basic actions, children thought that a novel word in a sentence like "She blicked her toy" should go with the causal scene, but had no such expectation about a sentence like "The toy blicked' (which just describes the outcome, however it came about.)

 

This show that preschoolers understanding of syntax and verb meaning is closely connected to their non-language cognitive representations. Our next questions: how do these connections get built? Do children begin with some assuptions about how language will be used to express meaning, or do they discover it with experience of language and the world?
